body.p: The months of cold weather are January and February. It’s time to sliding now days, everywhere boys and girls, even men too. Rose Ziegler of Lebanon, Pennsylvania, she was here last Thursday. She came down with Mrs. Ben Stucki. She stop at Indian Mission school at Neillsville, and she heard about this Indian Mission in here Wisconsin, and now she want to see herself and to know what it was. Mr. and Mrs. James Yellowbank were here last Saturday evening at D. D. Decorah place and quite a few Indians stop here to wait newyear. Mr. and Mrs. John Stacy, Alvin and Tillie Stacy went to Greenwood week ago last Monday to see how they getting along those two boys working their own farm. Indian Mission school teacher Mrs. Emma Olson report she had forty-five children go to school at present. She told Indian reporter to see the children how they work hard to study their own lesson and every one got clean come to school, and she thank for their parents for these children. Miss Matilda Stacy, forelady of the sewing project, she went to Indian hospital last week at Tomah Indian school, and Dr. told her she need rest for a few days and she went there for a week to rest. She came back Monday evening and she is working Tuesday again. Mrs. Frank Lewis went to Tomah Indian hospital last Sunday night and she is going to have baby pretty soon and her daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Decorah of Mauston were here to take care of her home. Mrs. Esther Black Hawk underwent an operation Monday at Tomah hospital. She has not been feeling well since September last and Mr. Black Hawk went to see her yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Daniel La Mere and Cicel Free went back to Nebraska last month and came again last Monday early morning and they brought back his sister, Mrs. Margaret La Mere Johnson. Too bad news— their brother Alex La Mere passed away a few weeks ago at Nebraska Reservation. He is nice old man. The sympathy goes to his family and sister and brother, and some other relatives and friends. His and friends. Mr. and Mrs. Ray White of Dells Dam, were here at Indian Mission last Monday and visit relatives and friends. A man hunting deer last fall had a very unusual experience. He saw a buck and he fell it with a shot. Being very eager he ran up to it and put his tag on the horn. He put his gun aside and began to take out his knife when the deer got up and ran off. In a few minutes he heard a shot whence the deer go. Going to the place he saw a man with rifle and at his feet laid the deer with his tag attached. He told the man that the deer was his as he put his tag on the other said “I can’t understand how you put your tag on him when he was running like that.” .
